BB991F30DFE50131AEB568A86D17958E.description: Make appropriate personal/lifestyle/technology choices, evaluate, observe, discuss/debate, recognize interactions and interdependencies at all levels, explain, describe environmental effects of public policy, choose appropriate course(s) of action.

BB98D870DFE50131AEB468A86D17958E.description: Integrated Standard: Science in Personal and Social Perspectives

BB989700DFE50131AEB368A86D17958E.description: Identify problem or design an opportunity; propose a design and choose between alternative solutions; implement proposed solution; evaluate solution and its consequences; communicate a problem, process, and solution; use computer software, device interfaces, lab equipment, calculators, and GPS; use presentation software and hardware, communications equipment, and remote sensing equipment; generate and manipulate data; describe the connection between technology and the state of current knowledge.

BB981340DFE50131AEB168A86D17958E.description: Identify questions and related concepts; design and conduct scientific investigations; use technology and mathematics; formulate and revise scientific explanations and models; recognize and analyze alternative explanations and models, communicate and defend a scientific argument, observe; experiment, measure, graph, evaluate, discuss/debate, research, collect/analyze data, imagine, diagram, concept map, engage in peer review, recognize experimental error, reflect, and predict.

BB978150DFE50131AEAF68A86D17958E.description: Understand significance of historical scientific events and technological advances; recognize/relate contributions of other cultures, groups and individuals; work as part of a team; build on work of others; engage in peer review; use logical arguments; rely on evidence; recognize/use new information; change hypotheses; identify/evaluate "great leaps"; recognize/evaluate what is and is not science.

BB973E40DFE50131AEAE68A86D17958E.description: Integrated Standard: History and Nature of Science

BB96FD20DFE50131AEAD68A86D17958E.description: Follow appropriate safety procedures when conducting investigations.

BB96ADB0DFE50131AEAC68A86D17958E.description: Students should communicate orally, through writing or through drawings.

BB9649B0DFE50131AEAB68A86D17958E.description: Students should begin to develop the abilities to communicate, critique, and analyze their work and the work of other students.

BB95ADB0DFE50131AEA968A86D17958E.description: Students' explanations should reflect the evidence they have obtained.

BB956F30DFE50131AEA868A86D17958E.description: Students should learn what constitutes evidence.

BB953150DFE50131AEA768A86D17958E.description: Use data to construct reasonable explanations.

BB94F2A0DFE50131AEA668A86D17958E.description: Students use tools such as rulers, thermometers, watches, balances, spring scales, magnifiers and microscopes to extend their senses and their abilities to gather data.

BB9471E0DFE50131AEA468A86D17958E.description: Students use tools such as rulers, thermometers, watches, balances, spring scales, magnifiers and microscopes to extend their senses and their abilities to gather data.

BB942A60DFE50131AEA368A86D17958E.description: Use tools to gather data and extend the senses.

BB93DFF0DFE50131AEA268A86D17958E.description: It is important to follow appropriate safety procedures when conducting investigations.

BB939CE0DFE50131AEA168A86D17958E.description: In earliest years, investigations are largely based on direct observations. As students develop, they design and conduct simple investigations to answer questions.

BB931780DFE50131AE9F68A86D17958E.description: Students should answer their questions by seeking information from their own observations, investigations and from reliable sources of scientific information.

BB92D640DFE50131AE9E68A86D17958E.description: Ask questions about objects, organisms, and events in the environment.

BB923DD0DFE50131AE9C68A86D17958E.description: An object's position or movement can be changed by pushing or pulling.

BB91ED60DFE50131AE9B68A86D17958E.description: An object's motion can be described by observing and measuring its position over time.

BB91A070DFE50131AE9A68A86D17958E.description: The position of an object can be described by locating it relative to its background.

BB915090DFE50131AE9968A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of the positions and motions of objects.

BB910880DFE50131AE9868A86D17958E.description: Some common materials, such as water, can be changed from one state to another by heating or cooling.

BB90AC70DFE50131AE9768A86D17958E.description: Materials can exist in different states â€“ solid, liquid, and gas.

BB905580DFE50131AE9668A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of characteristics of liquids and solids.

BB901460DFE50131AE9568A86D17958E.description: Objects can be described by the properties of the materials from which they are made. Properties can be used to separate or sort a group of objects or materials.

BB8FCF70DFE50131AE9468A86D17958E.description: Objects are made of one or more materials.

BB8F8520DFE50131AE9368A86D17958E.description: Objects have many observable properties including size, weight, shape, color, temperature and the ability to react with other substances. Those properties can be measured using tools such as rulers, balances and thermometers.

BB8F2E20DFE50131AE9268A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of observable and measurable properties of objects.

BB8E92C0DFE50131AE9068A86D17958E.description: See 21st Century Skills of the Iowa Core Curriculum.

BB8E4F80DFE50131AE8F68A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of good health habits.

BB8E0AC0DFE50131AE8E68A86D17958E.description: Humans have distinct body structures for functions including but not limited to thinking, walking, holding, seeing and talking.

BB8DC610DFE50131AE8D68A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of basic human body structures (human body parts and their functions).

BB8D7E30DFE50131AE8C68A86D17958E.description: Humans change environments in ways that can be either beneficial or detrimental to themselves or other organisms.

BB8D3400DFE50131AE8B68A86D17958E.description: Humans depend on their natural and constructed environments.

BB8CD840DFE50131AE8A68A86D17958E.description: Chapter 12 of the Iowa Administrative Code states that science instruction shall include conservation of natural resources; and environmental awareness.

BB8C8B90DFE50131AE8968A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of ways to help take care of the environment.

BB8C3980DFE50131AE8868A86D17958E.description: The world has many different environments, and distinct environments support the life of different types of organisms.

BB8BF930DFE50131AE8768A86D17958E.description: Organisms can survive only in environments in which their needs can be met.

BB8BB500DFE50131AE8668A86D17958E.description: Organisms interact with each other and their physical environment.

BB8B6CF0DFE50131AE8568A86D17958E.description: Organisms have basic needs. For example, animals need air, water, and food; plants require air, water, nutrients, and light.

BB8B0510DFE50131AE8468A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of the basic needs of plants and animals and how they interact with each other and their physical environment.

BB8A9E00DFE50131AE8368A86D17958E.description: Plants and animals closely resemble their parents.

BB8A5920DFE50131AE8268A86D17958E.description: Plants and animals have life cycles that include being born, developing into adults, reproducing, and eventually dying.

BB8A1700DFE50131AE8168A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of life cycles of plants and animals.

BB89D700DFE50131AE8068A86D17958E.description: Different species of plants and animals have different observable characteristics by which they can be classified.

BB899210DFE50131AE7F68A86D17958E.description: Living things share some common characteristics that are both similar to and different from non-living things.

BB894360DFE50131AE7E68A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of the characteristics of living things and how living things are both similar to and different from each other and from non-living things.

BB88C1F0DFE50131AE7C68A86D17958E.description: The sun can only be seen during our daylight hours. We are unable to see the sun at night because of the rotation of the earth.

BB888160DFE50131AE7B68A86D17958E.description: The sun's position in the sky can be observed and described.

BB884060DFE50131AE7A68A86D17958E.description: Seasons of the year, day and night are events that are repeated in regular patterns.

BB87F890DFE50131AE7968A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of events that have repeating patterns.

BB87ADC0DFE50131AE7868A86D17958E.description: The sun provides the light and heat necessary to maintain the temperature of the earth.

BB874E40DFE50131AE7768A86D17958E.description: Weather changes from day to day and over the seasons.

BB870320DFE50131AE7668A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of observable information about daily and seasonal weather conditions.

BB86B800DFE50131AE7568A86D17958E.description: Soils have properties of color and texture, capacity to retain water, and ability to support the growth of many kinds of plants, including those in our food supply.

BB866D50DFE50131AE7468A86D17958E.description: Earth materials are solid rocks and soils, water and the gases of the atmosphere. The varied materials have different physical and chemical properties.

BB862880DFE50131AE7368A86D17958E.description: Understand and apply knowledge of properties of earth materials.
